description: Late Middle English from Old French apoplexie, from Late Latin apoplexia, from Ancient Greek ἀποπληξία (apoplēxía, “madness; apoplexy, paralysis”), from ἀποπλήσσω (apoplḗssō, “to cripple by a stroke”) +‎ -ία (-ía, nominal suffix). See plague.

definitionGroups.group: (medicine, dated) Unconsciousness or incapacity resulting from a cerebral hemorrhage or stroke.

entries.meaning: (medicine) Gross hemorrhage into a cavity or into the substance of an organ.
(informal) A state of intense and almost uncontrollable anger.
